Award.AwardTitle: Dark Matter and Neutrino Physics with Cryogenic Detectors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Multiple astronomical observations have established that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of known particles. Deciphering the nature of this so-called Dark Matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. A leading hypothesis is that it is comprised of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, that were produced moments after the Big Bang. If WIMPs are the dark matter, then their presence in our galaxy may be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in detectors located deep underground to help reject backgrounds due to cosmic rays.

The Cryogenic Dark Matter Search (CDMS) Collaboration has pioneered the use of low temperature phonon-mediated detectors to detect the rare scattering of WIMPs on nuclei and distinguish them from backgrounds. This work will have a broad impact which extends beyond the dark matter search. The technical developments will further advance phonon-mediated detectors, which have already found many applications in science and technology.

This award will provide funds for three activities:
-- The SuperCDMS Soudan experiment is currently taking data which will have world-leading sensitivity to dark matter for masses below 5 gigaelectronvolt (GeV). The experiment will continue taking data next year, and the full set of different analyses of the data will take place over the next two years. MIT has taken a leadership role in the low-threshold analysis, and will continue to do so.
-- Play a central role in the design, prototyping, testing, and commissioning of the next-generation experiment.
-- Develop and prototype new low-threshold, low-background detectors with enough sensitivity to cover all the available dark matter parameter space for masses between 1-10 GeV down to the irreducible background from solar neutrinos.

This award will contribute to the training of undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, continuing the group's strong involvement in mentoring undergraduates from underrepresented groups by participating in the MIT Summer Research Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-term goal of this project is to improve our understanding of dark matter: what it is, where it is, how it interacts with Standard Model particles, and what its role is in the evolution and fate of the universe. In pursuit of this goal, this proposal has three objectives:

  1. Measure a dark matter signal or place world-leading limits for the WIMP-nucleon cross section at masses below 10GeV.
  2. Play a central role in the design, prototyping, testing, and commissioning of the next-generation SuperCDMS SNOLAB experiment.
  3. Develop a calibration plan to enable the determination of the energy scale of SuperCDMS SNOLAB detectors during their dark matter search. This is a crucial measurement to enable the interpretation of the data from the experiment as limits or signals from dark matter.
  4. Research the use of active veto detectors for future dark matter search experiments.

The specific activities and outcomes:

  •  Dark Matter Analysis: Our group took a leadership role in the low-threshold analysis of the SuperCDMS Soudan data. Over the last year we have joined the analysis of the small HV detectors operated at Stanford and are currently working on making a dark matter limit based on the data taken so far. These detectors are the same type that we will use for neutron energy scale calibration at the a neutron beam line with our Northwestern ADR.  Our postdoc Ziqing Hong is also part of the group working on studies in preparation for electron-recoil dark matter searches with SuperCDMS data. 
  • The SuperCDMS SNOLAB Project:  Our group participated in the successful G2 proposal for SuperCDMS SNOLAB, contributing to the writing, figures, and calculations for the proposal. Our group participated in the integration and tower design meetings for the SNOLAB project. We participated in the preparation of the dilution refrigerator bids and looked at the vibration environment given the use of several pulse tube coolers in the SuperCDMS Cryostat. We are leading the NSF-portion of the  commissioning and operations grant for SuperCDMS SNOLAB, and are the lead institution for the nuclear energy scale calibration effort of the collaboration.
  • Development of an active surface-event veto: We produced a detailed design of an active veto ring detector that could be used to lower surface backgrounds in future dark matter detectors. This ,included a full thermal model and a detailed mechanical drawings of the holder for performing the prototype tests. While thinking about the active surface veto proposed in this grant, we realized that another way to cut down on the backgrounds for next generation low-mass dark matter detectors was to encase the entire detector tower in an active veto, instead of building one veto per individual detector. The idea is to use NaI scintillating crystals for this veto. We made detailed GEANT4 simulations of both concepts and showed that factors of 5 to 10 in background rejection were possible with these vetos. 
  • New Lab at Northwestern: We established a new research lab at Northwestern University, where we have commissioned an Adiabatic Demagnetization Refrigerator for this research. Also installed were a clean room, a helium liquefaction plant, and all the supporting smaller items required to perform R&D at the new Northwestern lab.
  • Concieved a new low-background facility at Fermilab for dark matter research. During this proposal we conceived and negotiated with both Northwestern University and Fermilab the creation of the Northwestern EXperimental Underground Site at Fermilab (NEXUS@FNAL), which will consist of a shielded cryogen-free dilution refrigerator inside a clean room sited in the NuMI access tunnel. This site is 100 meters underground, with helps shield the experiment from cosmic rays which reach the surface of the Earth. NEXUS will be an integral part of the testing and commissioning of next-generation detectors with sensitivity to the neutrino floor in a low-background environment that is easily accesible. The facility is now in the installation process and will come online by summer 2018.
